clinical_study.brief_title: An Accessible Digital Intervention to Promote HIV Testing/Counseling and Prevention Among Adolescents
clinical_study.official_title: An Accessible Digital Intervention to Promote the Use of School-based Health Centers and to Empower Adolescents With Their Sexual Health

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: This is Phase II of a study previously registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT02812329). Phase II focuses on adapting and expanding the reach of a previously developed video game aimed at HIV prevention. The game will be adapted to include web access/distribution and be evaluated using a randomized controlled trial.

detailed_description.textblock:
The specific aims for Phase II of this study are to:
Further adapt and expand our culturally and socially-tailored videogame to have a greater focus on HIV testing and counseling (HTC) in addition to HIV prevention in an older age group of 14-18 year old boys and girls.
This will be accomplished by refining the conceptual model of the theoretical mechanisms of behavior change to be applied specifically within the game. New content will be created with additional input from 4 focus groups of 5 adolescents each (n = 20, aged 14-18) and these participants will also play-test the game. In addition, this model will inform new intervention manuals ("Game Playbooks") targeting these new outcomes. Building the new content from focus groups into the game are intended to adapt and expand its scope.
A system will be established for the newly adapted game for web access/distribution and program integration. Work will continue with commercialization partners on widespread distribution of the adapted game.
The final piece of the study will be to conduct a randomized controlled trial in 296 adolescents (aged 14-18) to evaluate the acceptability and efficacy of the adapted game on its new web-based platform compared with a set of control games.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in attitudes around HIV testing and counseling
primary_outcome.description: Attitudes around HIV testing and counseling will be measured using a 9 question instrument. Each question will have a five point Likert scale ranging from Strongly Agree

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in intentions to get tested for HIV at 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Intentions to get tested for HIV will be measured using a seven question instrument. Each question will have a five point Likert scale ranging from Strongly Agree to Strongly Disagree. Strongly Agree indicates a higher intention to get tested.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of students tested for HIV at month 1
secondary_outcome.description: The number of participants tested for HIV will be measured by tracking data reported by school-based health center staff. The school-based health center staff records (by study Id number) if participant came in for testing in the last month and the date of the test.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the number of students tested for HIV
secondary_outcome.description: Participants will be asked if they've ever been tested for HIV

HIV/AIDS knowledge will be measured using the HIV-KQ tool. The HIV-KQ is a 25 item instrument with true and false response options. The higher the correct number of responses, the higher the HIV knowledge.

Perceived Barriers will be measured with a two question instrument that asks participants what reasons would most likely keep them from getting tested if they thought they had an STI or HIV. The instrument allows participants to select all reasons that apply.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in self-efficacy around STI and HIV testing
secondary_outcome.description: Self-Efficacy around STI and HIV testing will be measured using a four question adapted instrument. Each question will begin with the lead "How confident are you…" and participants' responses can range from 0% to 100%, with O% indicating less confidence in being able to do the item asked.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in self-efficacy around overall health
secondary_outcome.description: Self-Efficacy around Overall Health will be measured using a four question adapted instrument. Each question will begin with the lead "How confident are you…" and participants' responses can range from 0% to 100%, with O% indicating less confidence in being able to do the item asked.

arm_group.description: The research staff will orient the participants to the use of either the active or the control videogames. Players in both groups will play through an online tutorial demonstrating the mechanics of the game. Each player will use a dedicated device to access their game on the web and a set of headphones that they will use during each gameplay session.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ability to participate in a web-based videogame (willing to sit for 60 minutes/session to play the game)
- Have not been tested for HIV in the past year
- Ability to provide assent/parental/guardian consent+
- Have a completed and signed enrollment form for their school's health clinic allowing them, if they choose, to access the clinic for testing and health care
Exclusion Criteria:
- Failure to meet any of the eligibility criteria
